Letter of Mr. Theodore Marburg Laid
Before Arbitration Society.

Hullabaloo Benefit and Concert Attended by a Large Audience-Good Program.

The Arbitration Society held its
regular bi-weekly meeting in the
Donovan Room, Wednesday, at 3
P. M. No program was rendered,
the session being given over entirely
to the transaction of business. The
president announced that he had
received a communication from Mr.
Theodore Marburg-, inviting the
Society to arrange a debate between
teams picked from the whole undergraduate body; the debate to be
held before one of the sessions of
the National Peace Congress, which
is to meet here May 3-5.
A committee has been appointed
to arrange a debate. The committee consists of Taylor Starck, chairman, Charles Leland Getz, and J.
Earle Uhler. The debate is to be
a number on the program of the
Congress.
A motion was carried empowering
the president to appoint a committee
to confer with Mr. Marburg. Details will be announced later. Two
new members were enrolled in the
Society. After the transaction of
routine business, there was a discussion of various plans which
might make possible such publicity
for the proceedings of the Society
as to justify the members in the
preparation of really careful and
elaborate papers.

The most elaborate concert given
this year by the Glee and Instrumental Clubs was held in McCoy
Hall last Tuesday night. There
was a large and fashionable audience present and also a very appreciative audience. The solos by
Mr. Ruth; "Professor Napoleon,"
by the Instrumental Club; and "A
Wonderful Babe," by the Glee Club,
won great applause.
After the concert, there was an
informal dance which was greatly
enjoyed by everyone.
The ushers were: Frederick C.
Lee, chief usher; Harry S. Dickey,
John L. Dorsey, Guy T. Hollyday,
J. Hubner Rice, and Ernest B.
Riley.

We do not wish to be continually
importuning our subscribers to pay
their subscriptions, but we must ask
that all who have not paid, do 30
as soon as possible. There are 148
subscriptions for the current year,
and *seven or eight for last year
still unpaid. \Ve cannot expect the
printer to go on printing the paper
on credit. We must fulfill our obligations to him as well as our subscribers are expected to fulfill
their's toward us.
There is one phase of college life
which is receiving entirely too little
attention at the present time. This
is the singing of the college songs.
Two years ago the singing of the
songs at the football games was
given a fresh impetus; but now,
except at the games, we never hear
the songs. This is particularly true
with respect to the "Ode." One
would scarcely believe the number
of men in the University who do
not recognize the "Ode" when 't
is ,played by the orchestra. It is
needless to expatiate upon the
beauties of this simple and beautiful song with its dignified and sententious words. It is enough to
say that it is a disgrace for any
• student to go through the University and not know the "Ode." A
very short time would suffice to
memorize the words, and the music
. can be found in the Hopkins Song
Book, which is to be had at any
music store.
The committee on student affairs
at Stanford University, fined a student ten hours' extra work for cribbing,• besides expelling the student

A. MARSHALL ELLIOTT

ALUMNI IN WASHINGTON MEET

A Volume of Studies in Honor of the
Famous Scholar by His Former Pupils
to Be Published in Spring.

A series of studies in the R9mance languages and literatures,
projected in celebration of the completion of the thirty-fifth year of
service in the Johns Hopkins University of the late Professor Elliott,
and now .being completed as a

spring of the present year. The
twenty-seven contributors vill incmule former students of Professor

The Alumni Association in Washington, D. C., held its annual
meeting and banquet in that city,
on Saturday, February 18. The
principal address was made by Justice Stafford of the District SuCourt. Other speakers were
Maj. H. J. Beyer, Dr. F. K. Cameron, Prof. Jameson of the Carnegie Institution, Dr. E. B. Rosa
of the Bureau of Standards, and
Dr. W. J. Humphreys. Prof. Jameson claims to be the oldest alumnus
of the University in point of attendance upon courses. He arrived
here for study a few days before
the second student came.
Major Beyer pictured the 'high
spirit of earnestness and enthusiasm
which characterized those w ho studied here in the early days.
Dr. E. B. Rosa pointed out the
great field that the government offers for the trained I Topkins man,
and also the exceptional opportunity
that the government enjoys in being able to obtain the highly trained
Hopkins man to do its work along
lines of technical and original research.
Officers for the coming year were
elected : president, Prof. 'Mitchell
Carroll; vice-president, Dr. Frank
K. Cameron; secretary and treasurer, James Lee Bost.
Those present were Prof. J. F.
Jameson, Dr. E. P. .Magruder, Dr.
B. J. Ramage, Dr. L. F. Schmeckerbier, Dr. Oswald Schreiner, Dr.
George Wood Binal, Dr. E. B.

Charles A. Conrad,'94, Dies.

Charles A. Conrad, A. B., 1894,
died early Wednesday morning,
the Belvedere Hotel. He had been
ill only a week with pneumonia.
Mr. Conrad's death came very suddenly, as he was a man of 36 years,
in the prime of life, and enjoyed
excellent health. He had planned
to go to Europe next week. Mr.
Conrad was a man well known socially, being a member of the four
best clubs in Baltimore.

The Turnbull Lectures.

For the purpose of commemorating the name of their son, Percy
Graeme Turnba, who died in 1887,
Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Turnbull,
of Baltimore, made provision, in
1889, for lectures on poetry to be
given before this University.
The seventeenth course of lectures on this foundation will be
given by Maurice Francis Egan,
Ph. D., LL. D., United States
Minister to Denmark, formerly professor of the English language and
literature in the Catholic University
of America. The general subject
will be "Typical Christian Hymns."
The lectures will be given in
McCoy Hall, at 5 o'clock, the topicS
and dates being as follows:
Monday, March 20—"The Canticle of Canticles."
Tuesday,March 21—"The Hymns
of St. Ambrose."
Thursday, March 23—"Later
Latin Hymns."

Mrs. Christine Ladd Franklin,
wife of Dr. Fabian Franklin, whom
we noticed in this column several
weeks ago, is perhaps even more
famous than her distinguished husband,,and is without doubt one of
the foremost of American women
now living. Christine Ladd was
horn in Winsor, Conn., December
r, 1847, of a long line of. Puritan
ancestry. She graduated from Vassar near the head of the brilliaat
class of '69, and in 1878 came to
the Hopkins to carry on graduate
work in mathematics.- In those
days it was an unheard of thing in
this country for a woman to pursue
post-graduate studies, and even
here at the new University which
was introducing so many innovations into the American system of
education, no degree was open to
her. Nevertheless, Miss Ladd remained here four' years, and was
a prominent figure in the life of the
University. Iier ability soon attracted recognition. One who turns
over the files of the University Circular for those years will often
find her name; and in the issue for
December, 1879, and again in that
for January, 1881, he will also find
a notice printed in small type and

THE NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 6, 1911
COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEws-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)

THE NEws-LETTER.
In THE NEWS-LETTER of last
week there was published a letter
of a libelous nature, in which the
circumstances of an unfortunate
occurrence at the Commemoration
exercises on February 22 last were
unintentionally, let us hope, misrepresented so as to place the chief
usher on that occasion, together
with some of his assistants, in a
very disgraceful light. Permit me
to subscribe the following statement which, I trust, will exonerate
the ushers•of manifestly unwarranted charges.
The details of this incident, which
the modest "Spectator" has endeavored to furnish with minute
accuracy, have on the other hand
been grossly distorted and 'hopelessly exaggerated. The only apparent disturbance occurred during
the course of the second speaker's
remarks, when some one, who
chanced to be sitting with the
ushers, but not himself an usher,
began to engage in a succession of
mirth-provoking remarks, and continued to such an extent that the
alumnus mentioned was twice obliged to request the garrulous one
to be quiet.
The occurrence was most unfortunate, and no one regretted it
more than I ; but I wish it clearly
understood that the ushers are not
the subjects for censure. I hope,
also, that the offended alumnus will
recognize his error, and will never
have occasion to feel aught but
pride for his alma mater..
•
Very truly yours, .
HAROLD B. HERING,

To the Editor of

in the past, and it has failed. As
long as present conditions continue,
any further attempt must also fail.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LaTER.
In a recent issue of THE NEWSLETTER I noted the plans for a
class basketball series. As captain
of the first (and 1 believe the last)
varsity team at Hopkins, I am
deeply interested in a revival of the
sport.
In 1905 it was plainly shown that
Hopkins could support a team. A
season of five games with other
universities was financed without
official support, and the sale of
tickets met all expenses. Student
interest in the game was keen and
the number of men wanting exercise in the daily practice was gratifying. Naturally enough for the
first season, the team was selected
mainly from graduate and medical
students who had been veterans
elsewhere.
Yet for several reasons I believe
that better team work can be obtained from an undergraduate squad
and this class series will develop
men for a varsity next year, perhaps. Hopkins needs a winter game
to sustain athletic interest and give
everybody a chance to take that sort
of exercise. And when a larger
gymnasium is built at Homewood,
. n experienced
we want to see a
squad to select from. Push the
undergraduate series.
Very truly,
HARRY N. HOLMES, PH. D.,'07.

Hullabaloo Benefit and Concert Attended by a Large Audience-Good Program.

The Arbitration Society held its
regular bi-weekly meeting in the
Donovan Room, Wednesday, at 3
P. M. No program was rendered,
the session being given over entirely
to the transaction of business. The
president announced that he had
received a communication from Mr.
Theodore Marburg-, inviting the
Society to arrange a debate between
teams picked from the whole undergraduate body; the debate to be
held before one of the sessions of
the National Peace Congress, which
is to meet here May 3-5.
A committee has been appointed
to arrange a debate. The committee consists of Taylor Starck, chairman, Charles Leland Getz, and J.
Earle Uhler. The debate is to be
a number on the program of the
Congress.
A motion was carried empowering
the president to appoint a committee
to confer with Mr. Marburg. Details will be announced later. Two
new members were enrolled in the
Society. After the transaction of
routine business, there was a discussion of various plans which
might make possible such publicity
for the proceedings of the Society
as to justify the members in the
preparation of really careful and
elaborate papers.

We do not wish to be continually
importuning our subscribers to pay
their subscriptions, but we must ask
that all who have not paid, do 30
as soon as possible. There are 148
subscriptions for the current year,
and *seven or eight for last year
still unpaid. \Ve cannot expect the
printer to go on printing the paper
on credit. We must fulfill our obligations to him as well as our subscribers are expected to fulfill
their's toward us.
There is one phase of college life
which is receiving entirely too little
attention at the present time. This
is the singing of the college songs.
Two years ago the singing of the
songs at the football games was
given a fresh impetus; but now,
except at the games, we never hear
the songs. This is particularly true
with respect to the "Ode." One
would scarcely believe the number
of men in the University who do
not recognize the "Ode" when 't
is ,played by the orchestra. It is
needless to expatiate upon the
beauties of this simple and beautiful song with its dignified and sententious words. It is enough to
say that it is a disgrace for any
• student to go through the University and not know the "Ode." A
very short time would suffice to
memorize the words, and the music
. can be found in the Hopkins Song
Book, which is to be had at any
music store.

at Stanford University, fined a student ten hours' extra work for cribbing,• besides expelling the student
from the course.

The Alumni Association in Washington, D. C., held its annual
meeting and banquet in that city,
on Saturday, February 18. The
principal address was made by Justice Stafford of the District SuCourt. Other speakers were
Maj. H. J. Beyer, Dr. F. K. Cameron, Prof. Jameson of the Carnegie Institution, Dr. E. B. Rosa
of the Bureau of Standards, and
Dr. W. J. Humphreys. Prof. Jameson claims to be the oldest alumnus
of the University in point of attendance upon courses. He arrived
here for study a few days before
the second student came.
Major Beyer pictured the 'high
spirit of earnestness and enthusiasm
which characterized those w ho studied here in the early days.
Dr. E. B. Rosa pointed out the
great field that the government offers for the trained I Topkins man,
and also the exceptional opportunity
that the government enjoys in being able to obtain the highly trained
Hopkins man to do its work along
lines of technical and original research.
Officers for the coming year were
elected : president, Prof. 'Mitchell
Carroll; vice-president, Dr. Frank
K. Cameron; secretary and treasurer, James Lee Bost.
Those present were Prof. J. F.
Jameson, Dr. E. P. .Magruder, Dr.
B. J. Ramage, Dr. L. F. Schmeckerbier, Dr. Oswald Schreiner, Dr.
George Wood Binal, Dr. E. B.

Charles A. Conrad,'94, Dies.

Charles A. Conrad, A. B., 1894,
died early Wednesday morning,
the Belvedere Hotel. He had been
ill only a week with pneumonia.
Mr. Conrad's death came very suddenly, as he was a man of 36 years,
in the prime of life, and enjoyed
excellent health. He had planned
to go to Europe next week. Mr.
Conrad was a man well known socially, being a member of the four
best clubs in Baltimore.

The Turnbull Lectures.

For the purpose of commemorating the name of their son, Percy
Graeme Turnba, who died in 1887,
Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Turnbull,
of Baltimore, made provision, in
1889, for lectures on poetry to be
given before this University.
The seventeenth course of lectures on this foundation will be
given by Maurice Francis Egan,
Ph. D., LL. D., United States
Minister to Denmark, formerly professor of the English language and
literature in the Catholic University
of America. The general subject
will be "Typical Christian Hymns."
The lectures will be given in
McCoy Hall, at 5 o'clock, the topicS
and dates being as follows:

Mrs. Christine Ladd Franklin,
wife of Dr. Fabian Franklin, whom
we noticed in this column several
weeks ago, is perhaps even more
famous than her distinguished husband,,and is without doubt one of
the foremost of American women
now living. Christine Ladd was
horn in Winsor, Conn., December
r, 1847, of a long line of. Puritan
ancestry. She graduated from Vassar near the head of the brilliaat
class of '69, and in 1878 came to
the Hopkins to carry on graduate
work in mathematics.- In those
days it was an unheard of thing in
this country for a woman to pursue
post-graduate studies, and even
here at the new University which
was introducing so many innovations into the American system of
education, no degree was open to
her. Nevertheless, Miss Ladd remained here four' years, and was
a prominent figure in the life of the
University. Iier ability soon attracted recognition. One who turns
over the files of the University Circular for those years will often
find her name; and in the issue for
December, 1879, and again in that
for January, 1881, he will also find
a notice printed in small type and
appended to the roll of Fellows.
The notice reads:

new edition which is just from the
press. She was one of the boaal
of scientists, who, a year or so ago,
investigated the claims and unmasked the frauds of Eusapia Palladino; and since 1904 she has hell
a lectureship in logic and psychology in this University.

THE NEws-LETTER.
In THE NEWS-LETTER of last
week there was published a letter
of a libelous nature, in which the
circumstances of an unfortunate
occurrence at the Commemoration
exercises on February 22 last were
unintentionally, let us hope, misrepresented so as to place the chief
usher on that occasion, together
with some of his assistants, in a
very disgraceful light. Permit me
to subscribe the following statement which, I trust, will exonerate
the ushers•of manifestly unwarranted charges.
The details of this incident, which
the modest "Spectator" has endeavored to furnish with minute
accuracy, have on the other hand
been grossly distorted and 'hopelessly exaggerated. The only apparent disturbance occurred during
the course of the second speaker's
remarks, when some one, who
chanced to be sitting with the
ushers, but not himself an usher,
began to engage in a succession of
mirth-provoking remarks, and continued to such an extent that the
alumnus mentioned was twice obliged to request the garrulous one
to be quiet.
The occurrence was most unfortunate, and no one regretted it
more than I ; but I wish it clearly
understood that the ushers are not
the subjects for censure. I hope,
also, that the offended alumnus will
recognize his error, and will never
have occasion to feel aught but
pride for his alma mater..
•
Very truly yours, .
HAROLD B. HERING,

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LaTER.
In a recent issue of THE NEWSLETTER I noted the plans for a
class basketball series. As captain
of the first (and 1 believe the last)
varsity team at Hopkins, I am
deeply interested in a revival of the
sport.
In 1905 it was plainly shown that
Hopkins could support a team. A
season of five games with other
universities was financed without
official support, and the sale of
tickets met all expenses. Student
interest in the game was keen and
the number of men wanting exercise in the daily practice was gratifying. Naturally enough for the
first season, the team was selected
mainly from graduate and medical
students who had been veterans
elsewhere.
Yet for several reasons I believe
that better team work can be obtained from an undergraduate squad
and this class series will develop
men for a varsity next year, perhaps. Hopkins needs a winter game
to sustain athletic interest and give
everybody a chance to take that sort
of exercise. And when a larger
gymnasium is built at Homewood,
. n experienced
we want to see a
squad to select from. Push the
undergraduate series.
Very truly,
HARRY N. HOLMES, PH. D.,'07.
